thread.title: Feds bust woman with Hezbollah ties
thread.title_full: Feds bust woman with Hezbollah ties - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Feds bust woman with Hezbollah ties
text:
Getty Images/iStockphoto A Lebanese woman unwittingly met with an undercover agent from the Drug Enforcement Administration and a government informant over the last two years in both Brooklyn and Paris and allegedly plotted illicit deals for them. The feds busted a Lebanese woman on conspiracy charges after she claimed her Hezbollah "friends" were eager to launder drug money and buy cocaine and guns, according to court papers unsealed Friday in Brooklyn Federal Court.
Iman Kobeissi unwittingly met with an undercover agent from the Drug Enforcement Administration and a government informant over the last two years in both Brooklyn and Paris and allegedly plotted illicit deals for them with the Shiite group.
Kobeissi emailed the agent a shopping list from her alleged associates in Iran who wanted handguns, sniper rifles, assault rifles and ammunition, court papers say. She visited New York at one point during the investigation and stayed at the Waldorf Astoria.
Last March on Paris' Haussmann Blvd., as U.S. and French authorities watched, the undercover agent handed Kobeissi a bag containing $250,000 worth of euros. Kobeissi or an associate wired the money to Brooklyn through a bank in Dubai, according to the complaint.
Ali Hashisho/REUTERS Iman Kobeissi claimed her Hezbollah "friends" would buy guns and drugs, court papers charge. Kobeissi, who is charged with money laundering and weapon conspiracy, also allegedly claimed she had contacts in the Iranian government who wanted to buy guns, weapons parts and aircraft parts.
"So they can buy any quantity anything, anything, anything Iran," she said, according to a partial transcript of her recorded conversation with the agent.
"They will let you land without knowing anybody … They will send you a clearance … So you can go to Kish Island, you know it's on the frontier of Iran … it's like a free zone," Kobeissi said.
jmarzulli@nydailynews.com
